attributes.title: The neurostructural underpinnings of human fear learning and fear extinction – investigating the dorsal Anterior Cingulate Cortex, Amygdala and ventromedial Prefrontal Cortex

q1.value: Janne Nold, Mana Ehlers, Tina Lonsdorf

q2.value:
Description:

Understanding conditioned fear constitutes a vital part in understanding the development of anxiety and anxiety-related disorders (Lissek et al., 2005). Generally, the fear conditioning process comprises different experimental phases (Lonsdorf & Merz, 2017). Throughout the acquisition of conditioned fear (fear learning during fear acquisition training) an innately aversive stimulus, the unconditioned stimulus (US), is paired with an initially neutral stimulus, the conditioned stimulus (CS+), producing a conditioned response (CR) to the CS+ while a second control stimulus (CS-) is never paired with the US. Hence, the CS+ gains predictive power of the appearance of a US. Within the extinction phase (extinction learning during extinction training) the CS is no longer coupled with a US and an inhibitory extinction memory is formed. When later presented with a CS (retention test) one can either observe a retention of the extinction memory indicating dominance of the extinction memory or the return of fear responding (ROF) indicating dominance of the fear over the extinction memory (Myers & Davis, 2007). 

Throughout the past decades research mainly focused on the functional connections and alterations in cortical and subcortical structures in fear acquisition, extinction, reinstatement and return of fear (Hartley et al., 2011; LaBar et al., 1998; Lonsdorf et al., 2017; Lonsdorf & Merz, 2017; Phelps et al., 2004). Thus,  the functional activation of a neural fear circuit including structures such as the amygdala for fear learning (Cacciaglia et al., 2015; LaBar et al., 1998; Pohlack et al., 2012), the hippocampus for contextual conditioning and fear memory (Bast et al., 2001; Phillips & LeDoux, 1992; Sanders et al., 2003), or the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) in fear inhibition (Delgado et al., 2008; Hartley et al., 2011; Phelps et al., 2004) was at the core of fear research. However, studies regarding the structural basis of fear acquisition and extinction are still scarce and present inconsistent or even contradictory results. In the following, current evidence pertaining to the association between the structural nature of the dorsal Anterior Cingulate Cortex (dACC), the amygdala and the medial Orbitofrontal Cortex (mOFC) - as part of the vmPFC- and fear conditioning and extinction is briefly summarized. 

Especially the structural association of the dACC with conditioned fear has been discussed controversially in the literature. While some studies suggest a positive correlation of cortical thickness of the dACC with skin conductance response (SCR) to the CS+ – as a proxy of fear learning - during the acquisition of fear (Milad et al., 2007), others have not found this correlation (Hartley et al., 2011). However, Milad et al. (2007) found no correlation between the cortical thickness of the dACC and the SCR to the CS- or differential SCR. With this present study, we aim to investigate whether the cortical thickness of the dACC is associated with differential fear learning proxies (differential SCR and subjective fear ratings) of the acquisition of conditioned fear.

Similarly to the findings on the association of cortical thickness of dACC and fear learning, the association of amygdala volume with proxies of fear learning remains controversial. Whereas some studies have shown there to be no significant correlation between amygdala volume and fear learning proxy (SCR to CS+) (Hartley et al., 2011), other studies present findings specifying the association of the left (Cacciaglia et al., 2015) and right amygdala volume (Winkelmann et al., 2016) with differential SCR only in early acquisition. As it is evident, different studies regard different fear learning proxies such as differential SCRs or SCR to the CS+ as suitable and, thus, provide diverging results which have to be treated with caution.  Based on these diverging findings on the association of amygdala volume and fear learning (as measured by differential SCR and differential subjective fear ratings), the importance of a distinction between early and late acquisition shall be investigated in the present study. 

The functional role of the vmPFC in fear extinction has long been established (Giustino & Maren, 2015; Lissek et al., 2005; Morgan & Ledoux, 1995; Phelps et al., 2004; Quirk et al., 2000) but results concerning the association of its structural qualities with the extinction of fear are still limited and controversial. Previous studies have mainly focused on extinction retention rather than extinction itself (Hartley et al., 2011; Milad et al., 2005) and reported controversial results. Whereas some studies report that extinction retention in healthy individuals (as measured by the extinction retention index which was recently criticised theoretically and empirically by Lonsdorf et al. (2019)) is positively associated with cortical thickness of the vmPFC (Milad et al., 2005), other studies were not able to replicate this finding using a slightly different extinction retention index  (Hartley et al., 2011). Although these studies provide evidence for the structural association of the vmPFC with extinction retention, this current study aims to pinpoint the structural association of the vmPFC with extinction itself. Based on previous studies (Milad et al., 2005), the mOFC as part of the vmPFC constitutes a central structure in the extinction of fear especially in extinction recall. The mOFC will be our ROI in the present study, in which we aim to investigate the structural association of the mOFC with fear learning proxies (differential SCR and subjective fear ratings) during the extinction of fear. 

Possible explanations for the disparate results concerning the dACC as well as the amygdala might stem from different approaches when employing a fear conditioning paradigm. First, different reinforcement rates have been employed in different studies ranging from partial reinforcement rates (25 % - 80 %) (Abend et al., 2019; Cacciaglia et al., 2015; Hartley et al., 2011; Pohlack et al., 2012; Winkelmann et al., 2016) to full reinforcement rates (100 %) (Milad et al., 2005; Milad et al., 2007; Rauch et al., 2005). The reinforcement rate quantifies the extent to which a CS is coupled with a US throughout the fear acquisition phase. The rate of reinforcement might produce ambiguous (weak) or unambiguous (strong) experimental conditions (Lonsdorf & Merz, 2017), resulting in stronger (Dunsmoor et al., 2007; Milad et al., 2005; Milad et al., 2007) or weaker SCR responses (Cacciaglia et al., 2015; Hartley et al., 2011) to the CS+, which might account for different findings in functional studies. Still, studies investigating whether different structural qualities of the dACC contribute to inter-individual differences in creating ambiguous and unambiguous experimental situations are, to our knowledge, non-existent. Second, different reinforcement rates or explicit verbal instructions about reward contingencies influence the contingency awareness of a CS being associated with a US (Lonsdorf et al., 2017; Lonsdorf & Merz, 2017; Mertens et al., 2016). This might again change the appraisal of the stimulus as threatening and , thus, affect fear learning within the acquisition phase (Lonsdorf & Merz, 2017; Maier et al., 2012). Third, studies with large sample sizes are scarce (Abend et al., 2019, N = 351) with the majority employing extremely small sample sizes  (N = 12 (Hartley et al., 2011), N = 17 (Maier et al., 2012), N = 14 (Milad et al., 2007)). Especially the findings of these studies require further validation due to limited generalizability of the results.

The current study aims to shed light on the structural underpinnings of fear learning and extinction of fear. More precisely, we aim to investigate the association between the cortical thickness of the dACC and fear learning. Further, the association of amygdala volume and fear learning shall be investigated. Finally, the association between mOFC thickness and extinction of conditioned fear will be considered. For this purpose, brain morphology and fear conditioning data from a larger sample (N = 108) of healthy young adults with full reinforcement rate (100 %) and no explicit contingency instructions for CS and US will be analysed.

Hypotheses: 

1.	Firstly, we hypothesize a positive association between the cortical thickness of the dACC and fear learning (as measured by the mean differential subjective fear rating and mean differential SCR) in the acquisition phase. 
2.	Secondly, we hypothesize a positive association between amygdala volume and fear learning (as measured by differential subjective fear ratings and differential SCR) in the first half of acquisition (first 6 differential SCRs) but not the second half of acquisition (second 7 differential SCRs). Based on the findings by Cacciaglia et al. (2015), we expect that amygdala volume predicts differential SCRs in the first but not the second half of acquisition.
3.	Thirdly, we propose a positive association between amygdala volume and the fear response (as measured by the mean differential subjective fear ratings and mean differential SCR) in the extinction phase. 
4.	Fourthly, we propose a positive association between the cortical thickness of the mOFC and extinction learning (as measured by differential subjective fear ratings and differential SCR) in the extinction phase. 

Since we hypothesise a positive association of differential SCRs/differential subjective fear ratings with the proposed structures, we will conduct a follow-up analysis for each hypothesis to test whether the association of the according structure results from an association with the CS+ or CS-.

Exploratory Hypotheses:

Previous research suggests that the dACC is involved in the negative appraisal of threat (Maier et al., 2012) and, therefore, might only be associated with fear learning  in the early acquisition process. Hence, we propose that the hypothesised association between cortical thickness of the dACC and fear learning (as measured by the differential SCR and subjective fear ratings) is driven by the first half of the acquisition but not the second.

Further, prior research brings to mind that inter-individual differences in the conditioning of fear might stem from differences in contingency awareness in the acquisition phase potentially resulting from either explicit instructions about the contingencies of the US and CS or a full reinforcement rate (100 %, in the acquisition phase every CS is coupled with a US) (Hartley et al., 2011; Lonsdorf & Merz, 2017). We hypothesise that the dACC thickness predicts fear learning proxies (differential SCR and differential subjective fear ratings) but is moderated by different levels of contingency awareness.

One study described a distinction between early and late extinction phase when investigating the structural association with the mOFC (Milad et al., 2005) but did not report any results from this approach. Thus, we would like to explore whether there is a structural association between the mOFC and extinction learning in the early and late extinction.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
T1-weighted structural images (1 x 1 x 1 mm) were acquired with a 3 Tesla Siemens scanner using a 64-channel head coil and magnetization prepared rapid gradient echo (MPRAGE) sequence. The data of the present study was acquired in a previous fMRI study with a longitudinal mixed design. The baseline measurement consisted of a habituation and acquisition phase (Day 1) and an extinction phase, reinstatement and reinstatement test 24 hours later (Day 2). Additionally, we measured the Skin Conductance Response (SCR) for each participant to every CS+ and CS- trial during fear acquisition and extinction, the subjective fear rating of CS+ and CS- before and after every session and a structured interview on the contingency awareness was conducted at the end completion of Day 1
The previous longitudinal study included 6 experimental sessions (T0 – T5), with each session being 6 months apart. The first two sessions (T0 and T1) each comprised of two scans 24 hours apart. Session T2 – T4 consisted of a questionnaire battery, and session T5 again comprised of two scans 24 hours apart and took place 2.5 years after the first session (T0). For the purpose described in this pre-registration, only data obtained at T0 will be investigated.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value:
The data were collected as part of a longitudinal fMRI study over a time course of three years concerning fear and anxiety in the context of childhood maltreatment and life adversity. Behavioural, functional and structural neuroimaging data were acquired throughout the study. 
Data from the Baseline measurement used for the here proposed analyses were acquired between the 18.05.2017 and 21.02.2018. The subjective ratings (fear ratings) and psychophysiological data (SCR) have been checked for completeness, whilst the functional neuroimaging data has been analysed previously and therefore will not be subject of this present study. The structural neuroimaging data, however, was only checked for completeness and volume and surface of (sub-) cortical areas was extracted using FreeSurfer (V.6.0.1). 
For this study, the volume and cortical thickness of the amygdala and dACC/mOFC, respectively, as well as psychophysiological data and subjective fear ratings from Experiment Day 1 and Day 2 were extracted. To this point, no statistical models have been applied to the data and the data has not been combined yet.

question.value:
Participants were recruited from a larger, previously conducted study that subserved the aim to provide a pool of well-characterised participants that can be invited to subsequent studies. This previous study already required participants to be healthy and aged between 18 and 50 years.  Participants were contacted given they agreed to participate in future studies and had no history of childhood trauma, as assessed by the Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ; Wingenfeld et al., 2010), cut-offs according to Bernstein et al., 2003: emotional abuse<13, physical abuse<10, sexual abuse<8, emotional neglect<15, physical neglect<10)). Further exclusion criteria included claustrophobia, cardiac pacemaker, non-MR-compatible metal implants, brain surgery, left handedness, participation in pharmacological studies, medication, internal medical disorders, chronic pain, neurological disorders, psychiatric disorders, metabolic disorders, acute infections, complications with anaesthesia in the past and pregnancy. 
In total, the habituation phase (Day 1) consisted of 14 trials (7 CS+/7 CS-) followed by the acquisition phase (Day 1) with 28 trials (14 CS+ and 14 CS- in a randomised order) and an extinction phase (Day 2) with 28 trials (14 CS+ and 14 CS- in randomised order). For exploratory hypotheses, the acquisition and extinction phase will be divided into first and second half as based on previous studies (Cacciaglia et al., 2015; Milad et al., 2005). As described above, the first acquisition trial will not be included in the analysis. Hence, the first half of the acquisition will consist of the first 6 differential SCRs (calculated based on the first 12 acquisition trials) and the second half of the following 7 differential SCRs (calculated based on the second 14 acquisition trials). This also applies to the extinction phase. 
Monetary compensation for the participation amounted to 30 Euros per experimental session.

q11.value: Based on their screening for childhood trauma, 120 participants were initially included in the study. Only participants with complete structural and psychophysiological data as well as fear ratings were included in the present study. Hence, a total of 108 participants were included in the analyses.

q12.value: A power analysis (G*Power3.1.9.2) was conducted for the larger study which resulted in initial recruitment of 120 participants. In total, 11 participants had to be excluded due to incomplete data which provides a sample size of 108 participants for the present study (for exclusions see subsection Data exclusion).

question.value:
The main outcome measures are cortical thickness, subcortical volume, psychophysiological measures (SCR), subjective fear ratings and contingency awareness. The SCR was acquired during fMRI data acquisition using BIOPAC equipment as previously described in detail in Kuhn et al. (2020). The SCRs were then scored semi-manually using the custom made program EDA view (kindly provided by Prof. M. Gamer) that is used to quantify the SCR amplitude based on the trough-to-peak method with the foot point occurring at 0.9 – 3.5s after CS onset. The raw amplitudes were then normalized and range corrected by dividing each log-transformed SCR by the maximum amplitude (to any stimulus including the US) per participant per day. Processing of SCR data for this sample has been previously described and was left unchanged (Lonsdorf et al., 2019).

Subjective fear ratings were measured after habituation, after acquisition, before extinction, after extinction and after reinstatement. They consisted of two questions asking about “how much stress, fear and tension” the participant experienced when they saw the CS+ and CS- the previous time. The questions were answered inside the MR scanner by rating the answers on a visual analog scale (VAS) ranging from zero (answer: “none”) to 100 (answer: “maximum”). This was later transformed to a scale ranging from 0 to 25 (participants were instructed to rate from 0 to 100 on the VAS inside the MR scanner. The ratings were in steps of 5. Hence, the ratings are further analysed on a scale ranging from 0 to 25.).

Contingency awareness (conscious awareness of the coupling between US with CS+/CS-) was measured by conducting a structured interview with every participant after completion of Day 1. The answers were later coded into whether the participant was “unaware” (0), “aware” (1) or “uncertain” (2) of the coupling between CS and US in the acquisition phase. Participants were not given any explicit instructions about the contingencies of CS+/CS- and US at any point of the study. 

The first CS+ and CS- trials of the acquisition will be excluded from this present study resulting in a total of 26 trials for the acquisition phase (12 differential SCRs). The decision to exclude the SCRs to the first CS+ and CS- trials in the acquisition phase are based on the fact that the first CS+ appears before the first US has been delivered. Hence, the SCR to the first CS+ is not a proxy of fear learning since the coupling of the CS with the US has not been established yet. If the first SCRs to the CS+ and CS- were to be included this would distort the estimation of fear learning based on the SCRs in the direction of a less effective learning of fear based on the SCR.  
Sex and intracranial volume will be included into the analyses as covariates.

For the main hypotheses we will perform distinct multivariate regressions in order to test whether the cortical thickness of the dACC, the mOFC and the volume of the amygdala predict differential SCRs and differential fear ratings at different stages in fear conditioning. We will include sex and intracranial volume of participants into the analyses as covariates. As a follow-up analysis we will perform Pearson correlations for each multivariate regression to determine whether the structural association with the fear learning proxies is driven by an association with the CS+ or CS-. To do so, we will correlate the cortical thickness of the dACC, the mOFC and the volume of the amygdala with the averaged SCRs to CS+ and CS- and the averaged fear ratings for the CS+ and CS-.

q18.value: For transformations and coding of (categorical) data see subsection Measured variables.

q19.value: We will use p < 0.05 as criterion to determine whether the results of the regressions and correlations are significantly different to those expected by the null hypotheses. We will also apply the criterion of p < 0.05 to the ANOVA to test for statistical significance. The regions of interest (dACC, amygdala and mOFC) are implemented in FreeSurfer (V.6.0.1.) and will be used for this study.

q20.value: For Day 1, one participant had to be excluded due to a deviating protocol and two participants were excluded due to non-responding (in SCR only). On Day 2, three participants had to be excluded due to technical reasons with the MR scanner. Further, five participants had to be excluded due to non-responding to the SCR (as assessed as non-responding to the US). Physiological “non-responding” (as measured by SCR) on Day 1 and Day 2 was defined as no reaction in SCR to the US on more than 9 (out of 14) occasions. Due to overall missing data, one participant was excluded (see Appendix Figure 1).

q21.value: Missing structural data due to technical difficulties in MRI acquisition or deviating acquisition protocols will lead to a general exclusion of the participant. Missing data in subjective fear ratings as well as physiological non-responding in SCR will also result in a general exclusion of the participant from the study. Incomplete data in contingency awareness will not result in an exclusion of the participant.

q22.value:
Since we expect a stronger association between cortical thickness of the dACC and fear learning in the first relative to the second half of acquisition, we will compare the model fit of the multivariate regression for the association of the dACC cortical thickness and differential SCRs/differential fear ratings of the first and second half of acquisition.

In order to examine the effect of contingency awareness and cortical thickness of the dACC on fear learning proxies (differential SCR and differential subjective fear ratings) we will administer a moderated regression. The moderator variable is contingency awareness with the levels “unaware”, “aware” and “uncertain”. The dependent variable is the averaged differential SCR and averaged differential fear rating, whereas cortical thickness of the dACC is the independent variable. We expect that the association of the cortical thickness of the dACC and fear learning proxies is moderated by contingency awareness.

Regarding the association of the cortical thickness of the mOFC with fear learning proxies (differential SCR and differential subjective fear ratings), we will test whether this association is driven by the first or the second half of extinction. For this purpose, we will again compare the model fit of the multivariate regression of the first and second half of acquisition by using an ANOVA.

When later presented with a CS (retention test) one can either observe a retention of the extinction memory indicating dominance of the extinction memory or the return of fear responding (ROF) indicating dominance of the fear over the extinction memory (Myers & Davis, 2007). 

Throughout the past decades research mainly focused on the functional connections and alterations in cortical and subcortical structures in fear acquisition, extinction, reinstatement and return of fear (Hartley et al., 2011; LaBar et al., 1998; Lonsdorf et al., 2017; Lonsdorf & Merz, 2017; Phelps et al., 2004). Thus,  the functional activation of a neural fear circuit including structures such as the amygdala for fear learning (Cacciaglia et al., 2015; LaBar et al., 1998; Pohlack et al., 2012), the hippocampus for contextual conditioning and fear memory (Bast et al., 2001; Phillips & LeDoux, 1992; Sanders et al., 2003), or the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) in fear inhibition (Delgado et al., 2008; Hartley et al., 2011; Phelps et al., 2004) was at the core of fear research. However, studies regarding the structural basis of fear acquisition and extinction are still scarce and present inconsistent or even contradictory results. In the following, current evidence pertaining to the association between the structural nature of the dorsal Anterior Cingulate Cortex (dACC), the amygdala and the medial Orbitofrontal Cortex (mOFC) - as part of the vmPFC- and fear conditioning and extinction is briefly summarized. 

Especially the structural association of the dACC with conditioned fear has been discussed controversially in the literature. While some studies suggest a positive correlation of cortical thickness of the dACC with skin conductance response (SCR) to the CS+ – as a proxy of fear learning - during the acquisition of fear (Milad et al., 2007), others have not found this correlation (Hartley et al., 2011). However, Milad et al. (2007) found no correlation between the cortical thickness of the dACC and the SCR to the CS- or differential SCR. With this present study, we aim to investigate whether the cortical thickness of the dACC is associated with differential fear learning proxies (differential SCR and subjective fear ratings) of the acquisition of conditioned fear.

Similarly to the findings on the association of cortical thickness of dACC and fear learning, the association of amygdala volume with proxies of fear learning remains controversial. Whereas some studies have shown there to be no significant correlation between amygdala volume and fear learning proxy (SCR to CS+) (Hartley et al., 2011), other studies present findings specifying the association of the left (Cacciaglia et al., 2015) and right amygdala volume (Winkelmann et al., 2016) with differential SCR only in early acquisition. As it is evident, different studies regard different fear learning proxies such as differential SCRs or SCR to the CS+ as suitable and, thus, provide diverging results which have to be treated with caution.  Based on these diverging findings on the association of amygdala volume and fear learning (as measured by differential SCR and differential subjective fear ratings), the importance of a distinction between early and late acquisition shall be investigated in the present study. 

The functional role of the vmPFC in fear extinction has long been established (Giustino & Maren, 2015; Lissek et al., 2005; Morgan & Ledoux, 1995; Phelps et al., 2004; Quirk et al., 2000) but results concerning the association of its structural qualities with the extinction of fear are still limited and controversial. Previous studies have mainly focused on extinction retention rather than extinction itself (Hartley et al., 2011; Milad et al., 2005) and reported controversial results. Whereas some studies report that extinction retention in healthy individuals (as measured by the extinction retention index which was recently criticised theoretically and empirically by Lonsdorf et al. (2019)) is positively associated with cortical thickness of the vmPFC (Milad et al., 2005), other studies were not able to replicate this finding using a slightly different extinction retention index  (Hartley et al., 2011). Although these studies provide evidence for the structural association of the vmPFC with extinction retention, this current study aims to pinpoint the structural association of the vmPFC with extinction itself. Based on previous studies (Milad et al., 2005), the mOFC as part of the vmPFC constitutes a central structure in the extinction of fear especially in extinction recall. The mOFC will be our ROI in the present study, in which we aim to investigate the structural association of the mOFC with fear learning proxies (differential SCR and subjective fear ratings) during the extinction of fear. 

Possible explanations for the disparate results concerning the dACC as well as the amygdala might stem from different approaches when employing a fear conditioning paradigm. First, different reinforcement rates have been employed in different studies ranging from partial reinforcement rates (25 % - 80 %) (Abend et al., 2019; Cacciaglia et al., 2015; Hartley et al., 2011; Pohlack et al., 2012; Winkelmann et al., 2016) to full reinforcement rates (100 %) (Milad et al., 2005; Milad et al., 2007; Rauch et al., 2005). The reinforcement rate quantifies the extent to which a CS is coupled with a US throughout the fear acquisition phase. The rate of reinforcement might produce ambiguous (weak) or unambiguous (strong) experimental conditions (Lonsdorf & Merz, 2017), resulting in stronger (Dunsmoor et al., 2007; Milad et al., 2005; Milad et al., 2007) or weaker SCR responses (Cacciaglia et al., 2015; Hartley et al., 2011) to the CS+, which might account for different findings in functional studies. Still, studies investigating whether different structural qualities of the dACC contribute to inter-individual differences in creating ambiguous and unambiguous experimental situations are, to our knowledge, non-existent. Second, different reinforcement rates or explicit verbal instructions about reward contingencies influence the contingency awareness of a CS being associated with a US (Lonsdorf et al., 2017; Lonsdorf & Merz, 2017; Mertens et al., 2016). This might again change the appraisal of the stimulus as threatening and , thus, affect fear learning within the acquisition phase (Lonsdorf & Merz, 2017; Maier et al., 2012). Third, studies with large sample sizes are scarce (Abend et al., 2019, N = 351) with the majority employing extremely small sample sizes  (N = 12 (Hartley et al., 2011), N = 17 (Maier et al., 2012), N = 14 (Milad et al., 2007)). Especially the findings of these studies require further validation due to limited generalizability of the results.

The current study aims to shed light on the structural underpinnings of fear learning and extinction of fear. More precisely, we aim to investigate the association between the cortical thickness of the dACC and fear learning. Further, the association of amygdala volume and fear learning shall be investigated. Finally, the association between mOFC thickness and extinction of conditioned fear will be considered. For this purpose, brain morphology and fear conditioning data from a larger sample (N = 108) of healthy young adults with full reinforcement rate (100 %) and no explicit contingency instructions for CS and US will be analysed.

Hypotheses: 

1.	Firstly, we hypothesize a positive association between the cortical thickness of the dACC and fear learning (as measured by the mean differential subjective fear rating and mean differential SCR) in the acquisition phase. 
2.	Secondly, we hypothesize a positive association between amygdala volume and fear learning (as measured by differential subjective fear ratings and differential SCR) in the first half of acquisition (first 6 differential SCRs) but not the second half of acquisition (second 7 differential SCRs). Based on the findings by Cacciaglia et al. (2015), we expect that amygdala volume predicts differential SCRs in the first but not the second half of acquisition.
3.	Thirdly, we propose a positive association between amygdala volume and the fear response (as measured by the mean differential subjective fear ratings and mean differential SCR) in the extinction phase. 
4.	Fourthly, we propose a positive association between the cortical thickness of the mOFC and extinction learning (as measured by differential subjective fear ratings and differential SCR) in the extinction phase. 

Since we hypothesise a positive association of differential SCRs/differential subjective fear ratings with the proposed structures, we will conduct a follow-up analysis for each hypothesis to test whether the association of the according structure results from an association with the CS+ or CS-.

Exploratory Hypotheses:

Previous research suggests that the dACC is involved in the negative appraisal of threat (Maier et al., 2012) and, therefore, might only be associated with fear learning  in the early acquisition process. Hence, we propose that the hypothesised association between cortical thickness of the dACC and fear learning (as measured by the differential SCR and subjective fear ratings) is driven by the first half of the acquisition but not the second.

Further, prior research brings to mind that inter-individual differences in the conditioning of fear might stem from differences in contingency awareness in the acquisition phase potentially resulting from either explicit instructions about the contingencies of the US and CS or a full reinforcement rate (100 %, in the acquisition phase every CS is coupled with a US) (Hartley et al., 2011; Lonsdorf & Merz, 2017). We hypothesise that the dACC thickness predicts fear learning proxies (differential SCR and differential subjective fear ratings) but is moderated by different levels of contingency awareness.

One study described a distinction between early and late extinction phase when investigating the structural association with the mOFC (Milad et al., 2005) but did not report any results from this approach. Thus, we would like to explore whether there is a structural association between the mOFC and extinction learning in the early and late extinction.
registration_responses.q3: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q4: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q9:
The data were collected as part of a longitudinal fMRI study over a time course of three years concerning fear and anxiety in the context of childhood maltreatment and life adversity. Behavioural, functional and structural neuroimaging data were acquired throughout the study. 
Data from the Baseline measurement used for the here proposed analyses were acquired between the 18.05.2017 and 21.02.2018. The subjective ratings (fear ratings) and psychophysiological data (SCR) have been checked for completeness, whilst the functional neuroimaging data has been analysed previously and therefore will not be subject of this present study. The structural neuroimaging data, however, was only checked for completeness and volume and surface of (sub-) cortical areas was extracted using FreeSurfer (V.6.0.1). 
For this study, the volume and cortical thickness of the amygdala and dACC/mOFC, respectively, as well as psychophysiological data and subjective fear ratings from Experiment Day 1 and Day 2 were extracted. To this point, no statistical models have been applied to the data and the data has not been combined yet.
registration_responses.q11: Based on their screening for childhood trauma, 120 participants were initially included in the study. Only participants with complete structural and psychophysiological data as well as fear ratings were included in the present study. Hence, a total of 108 participants were included in the analyses.
registration_responses.q12: A power analysis (G*Power3.1.9.2) was conducted for the larger study which resulted in initial recruitment of 120 participants. In total, 11 participants had to be excluded due to incomplete data which provides a sample size of 108 participants for the present study (for exclusions see subsection Data exclusion).
registration_responses.q18: For transformations and coding of (categorical) data see subsection Measured variables.
registration_responses.q19: We will use p < 0.05 as criterion to determine whether the results of the regressions and correlations are significantly different to those expected by the null hypotheses. We will also apply the criterion of p < 0.05 to the ANOVA to test for statistical significance. The regions of interest (dACC, amygdala and mOFC) are implemented in FreeSurfer (V.6.0.1.) and will be used for this study.
registration_responses.q20: For Day 1, one participant had to be excluded due to a deviating protocol and two participants were excluded due to non-responding (in SCR only). On Day 2, three participants had to be excluded due to technical reasons with the MR scanner. Further, five participants had to be excluded due to non-responding to the SCR (as assessed as non-responding to the US). Physiological “non-responding” (as measured by SCR) on Day 1 and Day 2 was defined as no reaction in SCR to the US on more than 9 (out of 14) occasions. Due to overall missing data, one participant was excluded (see Appendix Figure 1).
registration_responses.q21: Missing structural data due to technical difficulties in MRI acquisition or deviating acquisition protocols will lead to a general exclusion of the participant. Missing data in subjective fear ratings as well as physiological non-responding in SCR will also result in a general exclusion of the participant from the study. Incomplete data in contingency awareness will not result in an exclusion of the participant.
registration_responses.q22:
Since we expect a stronger association between cortical thickness of the dACC and fear learning in the first relative to the second half of acquisition, we will compare the model fit of the multivariate regression for the association of the dACC cortical thickness and differential SCRs/differential fear ratings of the first and second half of acquisition.

In order to examine the effect of contingency awareness and cortical thickness of the dACC on fear learning proxies (differential SCR and differential subjective fear ratings) we will administer a moderated regression. The moderator variable is contingency awareness with the levels “unaware”, “aware” and “uncertain”. The dependent variable is the averaged differential SCR and averaged differential fear rating, whereas cortical thickness of the dACC is the independent variable. We expect that the association of the cortical thickness of the dACC and fear learning proxies is moderated by contingency awareness.

Regarding the association of the cortical thickness of the mOFC with fear learning proxies (differential SCR and differential subjective fear ratings), we will test whether this association is driven by the first or the second half of extinction. For this purpose, we will again compare the model fit of the multivariate regression of the first and second half of acquisition by using an ANOVA.
registration_responses.q6.question:
T1-weighted structural images (1 x 1 x 1 mm) were acquired with a 3 Tesla Siemens scanner using a 64-channel head coil and magnetization prepared rapid gradient echo (MPRAGE) sequence. The data of the present study was acquired in a previous fMRI study with a longitudinal mixed design. The baseline measurement consisted of a habituation and acquisition phase (Day 1) and an extinction phase, reinstatement and reinstatement test 24 hours later (Day 2). Additionally, we measured the Skin Conductance Response (SCR) for each participant to every CS+ and CS- trial during fear acquisition and extinction, the subjective fear rating of CS+ and CS- before and after every session and a structured interview on the contingency awareness was conducted at the end completion of Day 1
The previous longitudinal study included 6 experimental sessions (T0 – T5), with each session being 6 months apart. The first two sessions (T0 and T1) each comprised of two scans 24 hours apart. Session T2 – T4 consisted of a questionnaire battery, and session T5 again comprised of two scans 24 hours apart and took place 2.5 years after the first session (T0). For the purpose described in this pre-registration, only data obtained at T0 will be investigated.
registration_responses.q10.question:
Participants were recruited from a larger, previously conducted study that subserved the aim to provide a pool of well-characterised participants that can be invited to subsequent studies. This previous study already required participants to be healthy and aged between 18 and 50 years.  Participants were contacted given they agreed to participate in future studies and had no history of childhood trauma, as assessed by the Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ; Wingenfeld et al., 2010), cut-offs according to Bernstein et al., 2003: emotional abuse<13, physical abuse<10, sexual abuse<8, emotional neglect<15, physical neglect<10)). Further exclusion criteria included claustrophobia, cardiac pacemaker, non-MR-compatible metal implants, brain surgery, left handedness, participation in pharmacological studies, medication, internal medical disorders, chronic pain, neurological disorders, psychiatric disorders, metabolic disorders, acute infections, complications with anaesthesia in the past and pregnancy. 
In total, the habituation phase (Day 1) consisted of 14 trials (7 CS+/7 CS-) followed by the acquisition phase (Day 1) with 28 trials (14 CS+ and 14 CS- in a randomised order) and an extinction phase (Day 2) with 28 trials (14 CS+ and 14 CS- in randomised order). For exploratory hypotheses, the acquisition and extinction phase will be divided into first and second half as based on previous studies (Cacciaglia et al., 2015; Milad et al., 2005). As described above, the first acquisition trial will not be included in the analysis. Hence, the first half of the acquisition will consist of the first 6 differential SCRs (calculated based on the first 12 acquisition trials) and the second half of the following 7 differential SCRs (calculated based on the second 14 acquisition trials). This also applies to the extinction phase. 
Monetary compensation for the participation amounted to 30 Euros per experimental session.
registration_responses.q15.question:
The main outcome measures are cortical thickness, subcortical volume, psychophysiological measures (SCR), subjective fear ratings and contingency awareness. The SCR was acquired during fMRI data acquisition using BIOPAC equipment as previously described in detail in Kuhn et al. (2020). The SCRs were then scored semi-manually using the custom made program EDA view (kindly provided by Prof. M. Gamer) that is used to quantify the SCR amplitude based on the trough-to-peak method with the foot point occurring at 0.9 – 3.5s after CS onset. The raw amplitudes were then normalized and range corrected by dividing each log-transformed SCR by the maximum amplitude (to any stimulus including the US) per participant per day. Processing of SCR data for this sample has been previously described and was left unchanged (Lonsdorf et al., 2019).

Subjective fear ratings were measured after habituation, after acquisition, before extinction, after extinction and after reinstatement. They consisted of two questions asking about “how much stress, fear and tension” the participant experienced when they saw the CS+ and CS- the previous time. The questions were answered inside the MR scanner by rating the answers on a visual analog scale (VAS) ranging from zero (answer: “none”) to 100 (answer: “maximum”). This was later transformed to a scale ranging from 0 to 25 (participants were instructed to rate from 0 to 100 on the VAS inside the MR scanner. The ratings were in steps of 5. Hence, the ratings are further analysed on a scale ranging from 0 to 25.).

Contingency awareness (conscious awareness of the coupling between US with CS+/CS-) was measured by conducting a structured interview with every participant after completion of Day 1. The answers were later coded into whether the participant was “unaware” (0), “aware” (1) or “uncertain” (2) of the coupling between CS and US in the acquisition phase. Participants were not given any explicit instructions about the contingencies of CS+/CS- and US at any point of the study. 

The first CS+ and CS- trials of the acquisition will be excluded from this present study resulting in a total of 26 trials for the acquisition phase (12 differential SCRs). The decision to exclude the SCRs to the first CS+ and CS- trials in the acquisition phase are based on the fact that the first CS+ appears before the first US has been delivered. Hence, the SCR to the first CS+ is not a proxy of fear learning since the coupling of the CS with the US has not been established yet. If the first SCRs to the CS+ and CS- were to be included this would distort the estimation of fear learning based on the SCRs in the direction of a less effective learning of fear based on the SCR.  
Sex and intracranial volume will be included into the analyses as covariates.
registration_responses.q17.question: For the main hypotheses we will perform distinct multivariate regressions in order to test whether the cortical thickness of the dACC, the mOFC and the volume of the amygdala predict differential SCRs and differential fear ratings at different stages in fear conditioning. We will include sex and intracranial volume of participants into the analyses as covariates. As a follow-up analysis we will perform Pearson correlations for each multivariate regression to determine whether the structural association with the fear learning proxies is driven by an association with the CS+ or CS-. To do so, we will correlate the cortical thickness of the dACC, the mOFC and the volume of the amygdala with the averaged SCRs to CS+ and CS- and the averaged fear ratings for the CS+ and CS-.

sample.value:
Data will be collected through a student sample who will participate for class credit. Since we are interested in detecting within-subjects effects, we are primarily interested in our episodic sample size. Since we are interested in repeated effects measured on a daily basis (i.e., effects can accrue over time), we wanted to be able to detect at least small effect sizes, r = .10. We used G*Power to conduct a priori power analyses. For an r = .10 and 90% power for a two-tailed test with alpha set to .05, we estimated we needed approximately 1000 episodes. We thus decided that our stopping rule for data collection will be 170 participants (x 7-1 episodes taking into account noncompletion rates).

We will use multilevel modeling to decompose the variance into within and between subjects. We are primarily interested in the within-subjects variance—in other words how variation over time within individuals in the predictor variables is related to variation over time in the outcome variables. 

Mediating Variables: We will explore mediational relationships between consecutive variables. For example, we will explore whether phone use in bed predicts sleep and how sleep influences affect, health, and health behavior on the following day. 

Moderating Variables: The overlap between Authentic and Social Self within each social context will moderate the effect of interpersonal interaction on affect. People with low perceived overlap between their Authentic and Digital Social self will not see a benefit to many interactions online, while someone with high overlap between Authentic and Digital Social Self will see more affective benefit from these interactions.

hypothesis.value:
This is a descriptive, correlational, exploratory study. 

The overarching question of the study is whether smartphone use and phone screentime should be considered a health behavior. Thus, the primary aim of the study is to explore whether phone use is related to other health behaviors—sleep, exercise, nutrition—physical health, and mental health, including positive and negative emotions, anxiety, and stress. 

A secondary goal of the study is to explore whether the way phone use is operationalized determines the strength of the relationships with health behaviors, health, and well-being. 

A third goal of the study is to explore how the perceived overlap between the social and authentic self in different mediums (in person, online, social media) impacts the well-being benefit received by interacting in those mediums.

A final goal of the study is to examine whether phone use is related to specific, rather than all, health and well-being outcomes.

Data will be collected through a student sample who will participate for class credit. Since we are interested in detecting within-subjects effects, we are primarily interested in our episodic sample size. Since we are interested in repeated effects measured on a daily basis (i.e., effects can accrue over time), we wanted to be able to detect at least small effect sizes, r = .10. We used G*Power to conduct a priori power analyses. For an r = .10 and 90% power for a two-tailed test with alpha set to .05, we estimated we needed approximately 1000 episodes. We thus decided that our stopping rule for data collection will be 170 participants (x 7-1 episodes taking into account noncompletion rates).

attributes.title: The effect of transparently different penalty rates on compliance with business safety regulations: a Prolific Study

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The effect of transparently different penalty rates on compliance with business safety regulations: a Prolific Study

other.value: We will explore the behavioral results based on the post-experimental questionnaire.

sample.value: We target to recruit at least N = 600 participants via the research platform Prolific Academic. The final sample size is determined by the available financial resources. We will first test 40 participants only to confirm that data is stored correctly and materials are displayed without any errors on various systems, and then continue with the remaining participants after this check. The hypotheses will only be tested after data collection is concluded.

analyses.value:
The analyses will be conducted using the r-package "lme4" to test linear-mixed models. The dependent variable will be relative compliance (percentage of compliance per round). Predictors will be entered as specified below for each research question. The predictors income and audit probability have three categorical levels. The lowest category will serve as reference category for each of the other two categories (dummy coding). 

1.) a) Non-transparent conditions: Linear mixed-model; dependent variable: relative compliance; predictors: business size, penalty scheme, interaction business size x penalty scheme; b) Transparent conditions: Linear mixed-model; dependent variable: relative compliance; predictors: business size, penalty scheme; interaction business size x penalty scheme; c) Finally, a linear mixed-model considering the complete 2 x 2 x 2 structure including all two-way interactions of the predictors and the three-way interaction is performed.

2.) Linear mixed-model; dependent variable: relative compliance; predictors: income level (refers to variation within the company types, i.e. low/medium/high), relative compliance costs, audit probability. 

3.) Linear mixed-model; dependent variable: relative compliance; predictors: business size, transparency, business size x transparency; only conditions with same penalty rates for small and big size companies considered.

All models will include a random effect for participants to account for repeated measures.

outliers.value: We will perform further analyses where we exclude participants who fail the attention checks.

dependent.value:
The key dependent variable is relative compliance with safety regulations, measured as amount of paid safety costs divided by the due safety costs. Participants are informed that during the study they will take on the role of a business owner that manufactures toys. In each round of the experiment they receive turnover (income) which varies for both big and small size businesses over the rounds, but is always higher for the big size businesses in comparison to the small size businesses. They have to spend a certain amount of their income as compliance costs to adhere to safety rules. This means they get a screen that informs them about their income in the respective round and the due safety compliance costs, as well as the chance to be audited by the responsible authorities and the potential penalties for noncompliance. Business income, safety compliance costs, and audit probabilities vary over the 18 rounds of the experiment. When making the decision whether to comply with the safety regulations in each round, participants have to fill in a form. The final payoff is determined by one randomly drawn round and based on the compliance decision in this round and whether there was an audit (and a potential penalty).

Several measures will be collected in the post experimental survey and are defined as follows: - Memory/attention checks (4 items; 3-5 options per item) – Manipulation Check (1 item; 5 options) –  Risk propensity (6 items) on a 7-point Likert-type scale – Norm Following (7 items) on a 5-point Likert-type scale – Severity of fines and perceived fairness (1 or 2 items depending on transparent or non-transparent condition) on a 7-point Likert-type scale – COVID-19 related questions (3 items) on a 7-point Likert-type scale – Demographics (e.g., age, gender).

conditions.value: The study constitutes a mixed-design. In eight different conditions, we test the influence of business size (two levels; big size company vs. small size company), penalty scheme (two levels; payback + 50% for both company sizes vs. payback + 50% for small size companies and payback + 150% for big size companies), and transparency of penalty scheme (two levels; penalty rate for other company size not transparent vs. penalty rate for other company size transparent) on compliance with safety regulations. These three independent variables are all manipulated between participants. Within-subject factors: All participants will go through 18 rounds of compliance decisions. Each round has a unique combination of the parameters income, compliance costs due, and audit probability (3x2x3 levels). Income is either 1000, 1500, or 2000 ECU (small size companies) or 1500, 2000, or 2500 ECU (big size companies). Compliance costs are either 20% or 40% of the income earned per round. The audit probability is set at 10%, 15%, or 20%, and audits will be determined based on these probabilities for each round.

hypothesis.value:
Theories of corporate illegality (e.g., Baucus, 1994; Coleman, 1987; Finney & Lesieur, 1982) assume three preconditions for illegal behavior of businesses: (1) the motivation to break the law in order to achieve goals or to ensure survival; (2) the opportunity to engage in illegal behavior; and (3) no effective controls to deter from illegal behavior. In line with the economics-of-crime paradigm (Becker, 1968), the traditional view is that illegal behavior, as - for instance - noncompliance with safety standards and regulations, should be negatively related to the level of deterrence. Accordingly, high compared to low penalty levels are expected to result in more pronounced compliance.

The aim of the present study is to investigate whether the effect of penalties on compliance is influenced by whether penalty rates are the same for different business sizes or not and if this is transparently communicated. We test whether the effectiveness of different proportional penalty rates for big and small size companies is attenuated or even undermined when such policies are transparent. In such a situation, different penalty schemes for big and small size companies could backfire due to reactance and negative reactions of disadvantaged parties, resulting in lower compliance. 

To study this, we use a between-subject design with a total of eight conditions resulting from three factors with two levels each: company size (big size vs. small size company), penalty scheme (same: 50% of evaded compliance costs for both company sizes vs. different: 50% of evaded compliance costs for small size companies and 150% of evaded compliance costs for big size companies), and transparency of penalty scheme (non-transparent/only informed about own penalty rate vs. transparent/also informed about penalty rate for other company size).

Breaking down our expected pattern of behavioral results, we first look at the four cells within the non-transparent factor-level. Here, we expect that safety compliance rates for big and small size companies are on the same level in the two conditions with the same penalty scheme. In the different penalty scheme conditions, we expect compliance to be higher for big size companies, which face a higher penalty rate. In contrast, for the four cells within the transparent factor-level, we expect a difference in compliance between the two conditions with the same penalty scheme, i.e. that compliance is lower for small size companies compared to big size companies. In the different penalty scheme conditions, we expect the difference between the two company types to become less pronounced, i.e. that compliance decreases for big size companies and increases for small size companies (compared to the respective pattern in the non-transparent conditions). 

With regard to evaluations of severity of penalties and perceived fairness (the latter only in transparent conditions), we expect the following pattern: in non-transparent conditions we expect higher perceived severity of penalties only for big size companies in the condition where the penalty scheme is different (i.e., only big businesses who face a penalty rate of 150%). In the transparent conditions, we expect higher perceived severity of penalties for big size compared to small size businesses when the penalty schemes are different and the reverse pattern when penalty rates are the same. The same pattern should also be observed for perceived fairness, assuming a negative correlation of perceived fairness and severity of penalties.

Research Questions:

1.) Does a different penalty rate for big size in contrast to small size businesses have a different effect on relative compliance when it is transparent compared to when it is not transparent?

Additionally, we investigate two other research questions:

2.) Do income level, relative compliance costs, and audit probability influence compliance with safety regulations?

3.) Does the business size (big size vs. small size companies) in case of the same penalty rate influence compliance with safety regulations in non-transparent and transparent conditions?

attributes.title: The impact of epidemics and pandemics on people with psychosis and mental health services: a rapid review

q1.value: The impact of epidemics and pandemics on people with psychosis and mental health service provision: a rapid review

q2.value: Richard Gray, Ellie Brown, Samantha Lo Monaco

q3.value: A rapid review of the impact of epidemics and pandemics on psychosis,  and mental health service use

q4.value:
We hypothesise that epidemics and pandemics will:
1. Increase the duration of untreated psychosis
2. Increase the incident cases of psychosis 
3. Impact the form and content of psychotic pathology experienced by people with psychosis
4. Increase demand for crisis care (community delivered crisis teams and inpatients services)
5. Effect the provision of mental health services to people with psychosis

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A rapid review of observational and experiemental studies.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will search MEDLINE, PsychoINFO and Web of Science using a combination of terms relating to epidemic or pandemic and psychosis (eg, schizophrenia, delusions). Studies will be included that report primary research (excluding qualitative studies), are written in English and published in a peer-review journal, where participants that have psychosis or are considered to be at high risk of psychosis have been at risk to exposure to an epidemic or pandemic and include data on the duration of untreated psychosis (DUP), incident cases of psychosis, psychotic experiences, or access to mental health services.

q13.value: We are undertaking a rapid review

question.value:
We will extract data on the following variables:
1. Duration of untreated psychosis (using any standard measure)
2. Incidence (new) cases of psychosis
3. Psychotic pathology (any standard measure eg, BPRS, PANSS)
4. Using of crisis services (community and inpatient)

We intend to undertake a narrative synthesis of included studies organised under the following five questions. Does community exposure to an epidemics or pandemics: 1. increase in the duration of untreated psychosis, 2. increase in incident cases of psychosis, 3. change the content of psychotic pathology, 4. increase the use of mental health crisis services, 5. impact how mental health services are delivered.

q21.value: This is a rapid review and no inference criteria apply.

attributes.title: COVID-19: perceptions and protective behaviours
attributes.description: A survey of British people's perceptions and behaviours toward COVID-19

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: COVID-19, perceptions and protective behaviours : a prospective survey

other.value:
Depending on the results of wave 1 and the evolution of the outbreak, changes may be made in the questionnaires for waves 2 or 3. Any such changes will be declared and pre-registered prior to data collection for the wave in question.
For obvious reasons related to the urgency of the situation, data collection was done two days before pre-registration. We believe that this pre-registration is admissible for the following reasons:
1) we have not yet analysed or even looked at the data.
2) we provide the questionnaire used, which prevents any a posteriori selection of variables that would have proved irrelevant.
3) Wave two and three data have not yet been collected.

sample.value: Our sample provider (Prolific) will provide a representative sample of N=1000 British residents stratified by age, sex and ethnicity. This sample size has been determined in order to have an accurate estimation (margin error < 3.02%) of the population's behaviour. Note that this leads to an overpowered sample for the test of the correlations and the multivariate models.

analyses.value:
Descriptive statistics of perceptions and behaviours of respondents at wave 1 and at follow up.
Crosstab of perceptions and the relative and absolute scores of protective behaviours by sociodemographics.
At each measurement time, two linear regressions with perceptions as factors and protective behaviour scores (absolute and relative) as DV.
At each measurement time, two global models with sociodemographics as factors, scores of behaviours as DV, and perceptions as mediators.
Exploratory analyses will be performed and declared as such.

outliers.value: We use Stevens (1984) specifications to exclude outliers (studentized residuals, Mahalanobis distance, and Cook's D). We will also exclude participants who report not having answered honestly or seriously. In addition, participants who take less than 2 mn to complete the survey or who did not complete it completely will be excluded.

dependent.value:
Protective behaviours will be measured by self-report using 10 items adapted from the list of 13 behaviours the NHS recommends people adopt in order to "avoid catching and spreading coronavirus" In the first wave of data collection, participants report the frequency of these behaviours before the epidemic and then during the epidemic (in the last 10 days). The items will be scored by summing them.
We will calculate a relative frequency score (frequency during minus frequency before) as well as an absolute frequency score (frequency during).

conditions.value:
There are no experimental conditions. All the participants answer the same questionnaire. We will test the following correlates of the dependent variable:
Socio-demographics:
Age, sex, educational level, civil status, number of people living in the household, frequency of social contacts, number of cases in the respondent's geographical area at the time of the questionnaire completion.


Perceptions (2 items for each construct unless otherwise specified):
Perceived susceptibility to COVID-19, Perceived severity of COVID-19, Perceived likelihood of coronavirus transmission, Perceived severity of the disease, Perceived self-efficacy of behaviour, Perceived outcome expectancy of behaviour for individual COVID-19 prevention, Perceived outcome expectancy of behaviour for the transmission of the coronavirus, Perceived outcome expectancy of behaviour for the spread of the epidemic, Perceived collective efficacy, Perceived collective outcome expectancy of behaviour for the spread of the epidemic, Perceived costs/barriers of behaviour (actual control), Subjective norm, Perceived descriptive norm, sucker effect (one item) and  free-riding (one item), Drop in the bucket, Reverse altruism, Exposure to messages about COVID-19 from lay people (one item) or from authorities (one item) and about protective behaviours from lay people (one item) or from authorities (one item), Incentives in the environment (one item), Perceived exposure to COVID-19, Confidence towards communication from the authorities.

For every construct, the items will be scored by averaging them (except for the single-item measures), under the condition of a correlation superior to 0.5.  If the correlation is inferior to 0.5 we will examine the face validity of the items and decide a) to use one item to estimate the construct or b) to remove this construct from the subsequent analyses.

hypothesis.value:
Our research goals are 
a) describing the status quo of protective behaviours, COVID-19 and SARS-CoV-2 perceptions in a representative sample of British residents
b) testing a model of the relationships between socio-demographic variables, perceptions of COVID-19, and protective behaviours
b) Monitoring changes in perceptions and behaviours during the outbreak

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
registration_responses.name: COVID-19, perceptions and protective behaviours : a prospective survey
registration_responses.other:
Depending on the results of wave 1 and the evolution of the outbreak, changes may be made in the questionnaires for waves 2 or 3. Any such changes will be declared and pre-registered prior to data collection for the wave in question.
For obvious reasons related to the urgency of the situation, data collection was done two days before pre-registration. We believe that this pre-registration is admissible for the following reasons:
1) we have not yet analysed or even looked at the data.
2) we provide the questionnaire used, which prevents any a posteriori selection of variables that would have proved irrelevant.
3) Wave two and three data have not yet been collected.
registration_responses.sample: Our sample provider (Prolific) will provide a representative sample of N=1000 British residents stratified by age, sex and ethnicity. This sample size has been determined in order to have an accurate estimation (margin error < 3.02%) of the population's behaviour. Note that this leads to an overpowered sample for the test of the correlations and the multivariate models.
registration_responses.analyses:
Descriptive statistics of perceptions and behaviours of respondents at wave 1 and at follow up.
Crosstab of perceptions and the relative and absolute scores of protective behaviours by sociodemographics.
At each measurement time, two linear regressions with perceptions as factors and protective behaviour scores (absolute and relative) as DV.
At each measurement time, two global models with sociodemographics as factors, scores of behaviours as DV, and perceptions as mediators.
Exploratory analyses will be performed and declared as such.
registration_responses.outliers: We use Stevens (1984) specifications to exclude outliers (studentized residuals, Mahalanobis distance, and Cook's D). We will also exclude participants who report not having answered honestly or seriously. In addition, participants who take less than 2 mn to complete the survey or who did not complete it completely will be excluded.
registration_responses.dependent:
Protective behaviours will be measured by self-report using 10 items adapted from the list of 13 behaviours the NHS recommends people adopt in order to "avoid catching and spreading coronavirus" In the first wave of data collection, participants report the frequency of these behaviours before the epidemic and then during the epidemic (in the last 10 days). The items will be scored by summing them.
We will calculate a relative frequency score (frequency during minus frequency before) as well as an absolute frequency score (frequency during).

attributes.title: Coronavirus threat predicts increased in-group exclusion towards Asians/White Biracials.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Coronavirus threat predicts increased in-group exclusion towards Asians/White Biracials.

other.value:
Exploratory Analyses of moderators will be conducted using demographic information (i.e., age, political party, political ideology, belief in coronavirus as a ‘foreign threat,’ gender, and education). In addition, we will observe whether the objective vs. subjective threat differ (and differentially affect outcomes).

We may do another time point later than the 3 months to see the pattern across a longer period of time after the virus has dissipated.

sample.value:
200 White participants, living in the US, over 25 years old during height of American coronavirus threat
200 White participants, living in the US, over 25 years old after threat has ebbed (i.e., 3 months after national emergency lifted)

analyses.value:
H1: Two indices will be created to measure coronavirus threat distance, and each threat distance index will be entered into the model as IVs:

A CoVID-19 threat distance index based on county will be created using the equation below:

=[sum(cases in county at time of participation)/sum(cases in USA at time of participation)]

A self-reported threat distance index will be created using the equation below:

=[avg(CoVID-19 anxiety/6)*(self-perceived impact item/6)] + [total (known positive tests)*(coded relationship item)]

Relationship item coding scheme:
Acquaintance, coworker, classmate, peer, or other socially distant relationship = .25
Distant family member, friend, or other moderately close relationship  = .5
Close family member, close friend, or other very close relationship = .75

Logistic regression will be used to assess in-group exclusion rates for White-Asian categorization based on these threat distance variables, SDO, and their interaction.

H2: Logistic regression will be used to assess in-group exclusion rates for Black-Asian categorization based on threat distance variables. Target race (A/W or B/W) of faces will be a within subjects variable. 

H3: Linear regression will be used to assess whether scores on race essentialist beliefs increase as threat increases (indicated by CoVID-19 threat distance index and self-reported threat index).

H4:  A moderated mediation analysis will be used to assess whether essentialist beliefs mediate the relationship between threat distance and white-asian categorization and whether social dominance orientation moderates this mediation.

H5: All analyses from hypothesis 1, 2, 3, and 4 will be conducted after data is collected from the second time point (i.e., 3 months after the national emergency is lifted), in which time will be an independent variable within the analyses.

outliers.value:
Exclusions - Observations will be excluded from analyses if (a) participants fail to complete main IV and DV measures, (b) completion times are too short (< 5 minutes). In addition, data points 3 standard deviations from the mean will be excluded. 

Any participants who pass screening but are not our targeted sample (i.e., any race other than White, under 25 years, not living in the US) will be excluded.

dependent.value:
In-group exclusion
Participants will see a series of 20 Asian/White and 20 Black/White photos and will be asked to indicate whether the person in the photos is White or [Asian/Black]. We will calculate the proportion of 20 photos that are categorized into the outgroup (Asian or Black) as a measure of in-group exclusion. 

Race essentialist beliefs
Race essentialist beliefs will be measured using the Race Conception Scale (Williams & Eberhardt, 2008).

conditions.value:
This study is quasi-experimental and correlational in nature. Therefore, participants will not be randomly assigned to experimental conditions. 

IV1: Participants will be in either one of two conditions based on time: the first condition will consist of participants taking the study during the coronavirus pandemic (time point 1) and the second condition will be data collected 3 months after the national emergency is lifted (time point 2). 

IV2: Threat distance indices will be created using the proportion of confirmed Coronavirus cases in the participants’ county and their self-reported threat distance perceptions.

IV3: Social dominance orientation will be measured using the Social Dominance Orientation (SDO) scale (Pratto, Sidanius, Stallworth, & Malle, 1994).

hypothesis.value:
Q: As Coronavirus becomes more of a close threat to Americans, will White Americans show stronger race essentialist beliefs and more in-group exclusion, particularly for Asian/White faces?

H1: We expect that, as Coronavirus becomes more of a close threat to Americans (as measured by confirmed cases in their county and self-reported threat distance), participants will demonstrate more in-group exclusion (i.e., more categorization of faces as Asian) when categorizing Asian/White biracial faces (i.e., Asian/White biracial faces will be categorized more as Asian than White). We expect this effect to be moderated by SDO (the effect should be most prominent among individuals high in SDO).

H2: We expect that, as Coronavirus becomes more of a close threat to Americans (as measured by confirmed cases in their county and self-reported threat distance), participants will demonstrate no difference in in-group exclusion (i.e., more categorization of faces as Black) when categorizing Black/White biracial faces.

H3: We expect that, as Coronavirus becomes more of a close threat to Americans (as measured by confirmed cases in their county and self-reported threat distance), participants will show more race essentialist beliefs.

H4:  We expect that increased race essentialist beliefs will mediate the relationship between coronavirus threat distance and increased in-group exclusion of Asian/White biracial faces and that this effect will be moderated by SDO. 

H5: We expect that, because the threat will be reduced at time point 2, that effects in hypothesis 1, 2, 3, and 4 will be significantly less at time point 2 compared to time point 1.

attributes.title: Does veneering technique affect the bond strength of bilayer Y-TZP? A systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: This systematic review is in accordance to the PRISMA statement. The “PICOs” for this systematic review is defined as follows:  Population: specimens with any geometry comprising Y-TZP framework; Intervention: veneering technique based on Cad-on or overpressing procedures; Comparison: manual layering veneering method; Outcomes: Shear, microtensile and retentive bond strengths; Study design: in vitro studies.

q1.value: Effect of veneering techniques on bond strength of zirconia-based all ceramic systems: A systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: Iana Lamadrid Aurélio, Ana Maria Marchionatti

q4.value: The null hypothesis is that the veneering techniques would not affect the bond strength of zirconia-based all ceramic systems.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of in vitro published studies.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: A comprehensive literature search will be undertaken through the MEDLINE (National Library of Medicine) via PubMed, Web of Science (Core Collection) and Scopus databases to identify relevant articles through July 2019 with no limit on publication year. Articles will be retrieved in PubMed/MEDLINE using the following search strategy: (((zirconium[MeSH Terms]) OR (zirconi*) OR (yttria*) OR (y-tzp) OR (ytzp)) AND ((veneer*) OR (bilayer*)) AND ((shear strength[MeSH Terms]) OR (bond* strength) OR (retent* strength))). A sensitive search strategy was adapted for Web of Science and Scopus.

q13.value: The sample size will be defined according to inclusion criteria:  in vitro studies; using Y-TZP framework specimens covered with a ceramic veneer; and evaluating bond strength regardless of the mechanical test configuration adopted, either immediately or after any type of aging.

question.value: A protocol for data extraction will be defined and evaluated by two of the authors (I.L.A. and A.M.E.M.). Data will be extracted independently from the full-text articles selected for inclusion using a standardized form in a program (Office Excel 2013 Software, Microsoft Corporation, Redmond, WA, USA). The authors will categorized similar information into groups according to the outcome of interest, bons strength. The authors of the selected studies will be contacted via e-mail if data are missing or more information is needed when studies do not report the precise values of bond strength (mean and SD).

Every possible comparison will be performed; when appropriate, specific formulas will be applied to combine data from multiple groups of a same study into single sample sizes, means, and standard deviation values. Pooled effect estimates will be obtained by comparing the means of each of the bond strength values, and these will be expressed as raw mean differences among the groups. A P value ?.05 will be considered statistically significant (Z test). The statistical heterogeneity among the studies will be assessed by using both the Cochran Q test, where a P value <.1 will be considered statistically significant, and the inconsistency I2 test, where values higher than 50% will be considered indicative of substantial heterogeneity. All analyses will be performed using Review Manager software version 5.3 (Cochrane Collaboration).
