attributes.title: Precision and reliability of manual physician vs electronic data collection of health information

q1.value: Precision and reliability of manual physician vs electronic data collection of health information for post operative nausea and vomiting

q2.value: Erika Strazdins, Matthew Miller, Simone Young, Kate Congreve, nicole kalish

q3.value:
PONV (post-operative nausea and vomiting) is a common and preventable side effect of anaesthesia. Rates vary from 10% to 80% depending on the presence of risk factors. Expected PONV management involves assessing patients for their risk factors, providing appropriate prophylaxis and charting rescue medication. To assess how well this is performed, regular clinical audits are encouraged. These audits traditionally involve following up patients for self-reported nausea and vomiting, and also reviewing paper charts for antiemetic use. This can be time consuming, risks human error, and not lend itself easily to repeat audits. However, with the advent of electronic medical records it may be feasible to perform an audit using electronic data. 

This study aims to demonstrate in a routine clinical audit setting how electronic data extraction may be of similar precision as the more traditional and accepted manual extraction. It is hoped that this can act as a step towards the more effective use of electronic data, and provide rapid, timely, and reproducible information that can be applied to improve hospital-based outcomes and practices within our health district. Currently, not all elements needed for a PONV audit are captured in the electronic medical record, however antiemetic administration and some risk factors are. This project will also assess how the addition of a few data elements not currently collected could be improved if included in routine data collection.

q4.value: For inpatient non-cardiac surgical patients up to 24 hours after surgery, manual data collection of post operative nausea (measured by anti-nausea medications) compared to an electronic data extraction will produce similar estimates of incidence

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: Retrospective chart review but manual data extrication (manual audit) and electronic data-linkage (electronic audit)

data.name: Appendix A Manual PONV audit proposal for OSF.docx

extra.selectedFileName: Appendix A Manual PONV audit proposal for OSF.docx

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The manual audit was performed and data entered by two researchers (Young and Kalish). They will perform the data analysis of PONV rates and prophylaxis for these data. These data exist at the time of registration. The electronic data will be accessed and analysed by a third researcher (Miller), who will also check the manual audit analysis and then perform the comparison between the two groups.

question.value:
Participants will be all adult inpatients who meet the inclusion criteria criteria (see below) admitted to the ward from PACU following a surgical procedure at St George Hospital during the study period.
Exclusion criteria are: Patients who have undergone endoscopy only, patients who have undergone ECT only, day surgery patients.

Data will be collected from two sources:
1. PACU PONV audit form (appendix a) which is to be complete on discharge from PACU on Day 0 by PACU nurses and then patient interviews on the ward on post op day 1. 

The second source is an electronic review of Electronic Medical Record which includes surgical details and medication records. All data will then be entered into REDCap for subsequent analysis.

q14.value:
stimated rates of PONV vary according to the number of risk factors. The following table presents the estimates of PONV and the sample size required to detect a difference in these rates. 

We will seek a minimum sample size of 193. 

# risk factors	Rate (%)	Sample size to detect difference between rates with successive risk factors
0	10	Rate difference to detect	Sample size (n)
1	20	10-20%	98
2	30	20-30%	145
3	50	30-50%	46
4	60	50-60%	194
5	80	60-80%	40

q15.value: The limitation on the sample size will be the manual audit collection, as this relies on cooperation with post anaesthesia care staff. Therefore this has been set at a two-week period, extending to a third week if post anaesthesia care staff agree

question.value: None, as this study is observational in nature.
Please review pages 6-7 of study protocol attached for variables

The Apfel Scoring System will be used to stratify patients as low, medium or high risk depending on the presence or absence of 4 risk factors, namely: female sex, non-smoker, previous PONV/ history of motion sickness, use of post-operative opioids.

Analysis will be performed using the statistical software package R (R Core Team, Vienna, Austria) and Excel (Microsoft, Redmond, USA). Descriptive statistics will be used to describe the dataset. The data analysis will initially be performed separately, with Dr’s Young and Kalish preparing the results for the manual audit.
The electronic data joining, and analysis will be performed by Dr Miller. After these results have been prepared, Dr Miller will also check over the results of the manual audit. 
After joining the data, descriptive statistics will be produced to describe the two datasets (manual and electronic audit).
Two compare the difference in PONV rates, point estimates will be produced with 95% CI , and then McNemars test will be used to look at marginal differences between the estimated rates. 
Two compare the differences in PONV rate by Apfel score, a table will be produced of the PONV score for each available risk factor (in other words the information that we have).
To compare the effect of adding additional variables to the routine electronic data collection, we will add the missing risk factor information collected from the manual audit (motion sickness, previous PONV, spinal morphine or N2O use) to the electronic data as if it had been captured, then reproduce the table for used for the available risk factors. 
Finally, as a measure of reliability between manual PONV and electronic audit, the agreement between patients who report PONV in the routine manual audit and those in the electronic audit using kohens kappa. 

Primary outcome
Comparison of rate of nausea (measured in percent PONV of operations performed) within 24 hours of surgery between manually collected routine audit data and extraction of electronic data.

A patient will be defined as having PONV if they receive an antiemetic in 24-hours following the end of their operation. 

Secondary outcomes
A. Comparison of the expected rate of nausea and vomiting between electronic data extraction and manual data collection using risk factors (using the modified apfel score for prediction) (expressed as a percentage of patients)

B.  Comparison of the rate of charted anti-emetics between electronic data extraction and manual data collection (percentage)

C. How the precision of the estimate in outcome 2 above could be improved by adding missing fields from the Apfel score to routine anaesthetic data collection (eg improvement in percentage)

D. When extracting data manually or electronically, were the same patients identified as being nauseated (in other words, did a patient administered ondansetron on electronic data extract also report nausea on manual collection of data) (expressed as kohens kappa)

q21.value: Normally distributed outcomes will be reported as mean plus or minus standard deviation, whilst non-normal data will be reported as median and interquartile range. Categorical data will be reported as counts and proportions. Ninety-five per cent confidence intervals will be constructed around all point estimates. The only significance test planned is the initial assessment of PONV rates. For the remaining comparisons, 95% CI will be produced to assess the overlap and variability in estimates.

q23.value:
We will attempt to prevent large numbers of missing data by only examining variables of interest to the study (more variables = more missing data). 
After data collection, the datafile will be examined for missing data. We will quantify the missing data by providing a table of the proportion of each variable that are missing data, as well as the proportion of missing data overall. 
This study interested in the missing electronic data that prevents us from providing a complete PONV assessment that is available from a manual audit – therefore some datafields will be missing 100%. It is hoped that by reporting these, steps can be made to improve future data collection.

q24.value: After the initial analysis is complete, we will attempt to estimate the PONV incidence over six-months using electronic data to try and improve the precision of our estimate

This can be time consuming, risks human error, and not lend itself easily to repeat audits. However, with the advent of electronic medical records it may be feasible to perform an audit using electronic data. 

This study aims to demonstrate in a routine clinical audit setting how electronic data extraction may be of similar precision as the more traditional and accepted manual extraction. It is hoped that this can act as a step towards the more effective use of electronic data, and provide rapid, timely, and reproducible information that can be applied to improve hospital-based outcomes and practices within our health district. Currently, not all elements needed for a PONV audit are captured in the electronic medical record, however antiemetic administration and some risk factors are. This project will also assess how the addition of a few data elements not currently collected could be improved if included in routine data collection.

registration_responses.q21: Normally distributed outcomes will be reported as mean plus or minus standard deviation, whilst non-normal data will be reported as median and interquartile range. Categorical data will be reported as counts and proportions. Ninety-five per cent confidence intervals will be constructed around all point estimates. The only significance test planned is the initial assessment of PONV rates. For the remaining comparisons, 95% CI will be produced to assess the overlap and variability in estimates.
registration_responses.q23:
We will attempt to prevent large numbers of missing data by only examining variables of interest to the study (more variables = more missing data). 
After data collection, the datafile will be examined for missing data. We will quantify the missing data by providing a table of the proportion of each variable that are missing data, as well as the proportion of missing data overall. 
This study interested in the missing electronic data that prevents us from providing a complete PONV assessment that is available from a manual audit – therefore some datafields will be missing 100%. It is hoped that by reporting these, steps can be made to improve future data collection.

registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be all adult inpatients who meet the inclusion criteria criteria (see below) admitted to the ward from PACU following a surgical procedure at St George Hospital during the study period.
Exclusion criteria are: Patients who have undergone endoscopy only, patients who have undergone ECT only, day surgery patients.

Data will be collected from two sources:
1. PACU PONV audit form (appendix a) which is to be complete on discharge from PACU on Day 0 by PACU nurses and then patient interviews on the ward on post op day 1. 

The second source is an electronic review of Electronic Medical Record which includes surgical details and medication records. All data will then be entered into REDCap for subsequent analysis.

registration_responses.q18.question: The Apfel Scoring System will be used to stratify patients as low, medium or high risk depending on the presence or absence of 4 risk factors, namely: female sex, non-smoker, previous PONV/ history of motion sickness, use of post-operative opioids.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Analysis will be performed using the statistical software package R (R Core Team, Vienna, Austria) and Excel (Microsoft, Redmond, USA). Descriptive statistics will be used to describe the dataset. The data analysis will initially be performed separately, with Dr’s Young and Kalish preparing the results for the manual audit.
The electronic data joining, and analysis will be performed by Dr Miller. After these results have been prepared, Dr Miller will also check over the results of the manual audit. 
After joining the data, descriptive statistics will be produced to describe the two datasets (manual and electronic audit).
Two compare the difference in PONV rates, point estimates will be produced with 95% CI , and then McNemars test will be used to look at marginal differences between the estimated rates. 
Two compare the differences in PONV rate by Apfel score, a table will be produced of the PONV score for each available risk factor (in other words the information that we have).
To compare the effect of adding additional variables to the routine electronic data collection, we will add the missing risk factor information collected from the manual audit (motion sickness, previous PONV, spinal morphine or N2O use) to the electronic data as if it had been captured, then reproduce the table for used for the available risk factors. 
Finally, as a measure of reliability between manual PONV and electronic audit, the agreement between patients who report PONV in the routine manual audit and those in the electronic audit using kohens kappa. 

Primary outcome
Comparison of rate of nausea (measured in percent PONV of operations performed) within 24 hours of surgery between manually collected routine audit data and extraction of electronic data.

A patient will be defined as having PONV if they receive an antiemetic in 24-hours following the end of their operation. 

Secondary outcomes
A. Comparison of the expected rate of nausea and vomiting between electronic data extraction and manual data collection using risk factors (using the modified apfel score for prediction) (expressed as a percentage of patients)

B.  Comparison of the rate of charted anti-emetics between electronic data extraction and manual data collection (percentage)

C. How the precision of the estimate in outcome 2 above could be improved by adding missing fields from the Apfel score to routine anaesthetic data collection (eg improvement in percentage)

D. When extracting data manually or electronically, were the same patients identified as being nauseated (in other words, did a patient administered ondansetron on electronic data extract also report nausea on manual collection of data) (expressed as kohens kappa)
